page.title: Unit 6 Overview: Why Should I Care?
page.contents:
Do you think you would want to open your own business someday? Watch the video to learn a bit about how Ozzy Gamez and Juan Quezada opened the Plant Shop Chicago and how they can use polynomials to make sure the business is successful.



In this unit, you will learn about polynomials. Understanding how to perform operations with polynomials can help you plan a budget for the school fundraiser so you can decide the best price to charge for the products and how to account for the shipping costs.

Building Character: Judgment

Ozzy Gamez grew up in Belize, and Juan Quezada grew up in Mexico. However, they had a mutual love of plants. Ozzy and Juan turned their love of plants into a thriving business. Plant Shop Chicago opened its doors in 2021 with the goal of growing the plant community. It takes hard work, planning, and a keen sense of judgment to grow a successful business. Plant Shop Chicago uses digital tools to make the business run efficiently. They could use polynomials to plan their revenue and costs so they can make a profit.

Throughout this unit, you will work on developing your judgment. We expect good judgment from doctors when they are treating us, teachers when they are grading assignments, and employers when they are reviewing resumes. A key factor in making sound judgements is not jumping to conclusions. Your judgment will never be perfect, but you can strive to be aware of bias and make corrections when necessary.

Think about yourself. When you face a problem that requires judgment, how many of these things are true?

  • I try not to jump to conclusions.
  • I am aware that this is a matter of judgment: I ask myself what someone I trust would think of this problem.
  • I independently ask several people for their judgment, and I consider their reasons.
  • I try to separate my hopes and fears from the facts and beliefs supporting the judgment.

Don’t worry if none of these statements are true for you. Developing this trait takes time. Your first step starts today!

page.title: Unit 6 Overview: Am I Ready to Learn This?
page.contents:
Getting Ready for Unit 6

To be ready for this unit, you need to be able to:

  • Simplify expressions with exponents.
  • Simplify expressions using the Distributive Property.
  • Find the greatest common factor (GCF) of two or more numbers.

Next, you will answer some questions that will help you see how ready you are for this unit. If you need help, some mini-lessons will help you brush up on anything you need to work on.

answer.response: $@NULL@$
$@NULL@$

page.title: Question #1: Simplify Expressions Using Properties of Exponents

answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The expression uses the Product Property for Exponents. To multiply with like bases, add the exponents.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The expression uses the Product Property for Exponents. To multiply with like bases, add the exponents rather than multiplying them. \(x^2 \cdot x^3=x^5\). The answer is \(y \cdot y^3=y^4\).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This equation uses the Quotient Property for Exponents. To divide with like bases, subtract the exponents rather than dividing them. \(\frac {y^6}{y^2}=y^4\). The answer is \(y \cdot y^3=y^4\).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This equation uses the Quotient Property for Exponents. To divide with like bases, subtract the exponents rather than dividing them. \(\frac {x^8}{x^4}=x^4\). The answer is \(y \cdot y^3=y^4\).

page.title: Simplify Expressions Using Properties of Exponents: Mini-Lesson Review
page.contents:
Simplify Expressions Using Properties of Exponents

In the expression \(y^4 \cdot y^2\) :

\(y^4=y \cdot y \cdot y \cdot y\)

The exponent 4 means there are 4 factors of \(y\).

\(y^2=y \cdot y\)

The exponent 2 means there are 2 factors of \(y\).

\(y^4 \cdot y^2=y \cdot y \cdot y \cdot y \cdot y \cdot y\).

There are 6 factors of \(y\), which can be written as \(y^6\).

\(y^4 \cdot y^2=y^6\)

Notice the exponent is the sum of the exponents of the factors.

When you multiply exponential expressions with the same base, you keep the base and add the exponents.

PRODUCT PROPERTY FOR EXPONENTS

If \(a\) is a real number and \(m\) and \(n\) are integers, then

\(a^m \cdot a^n=a^{m+n}\)

To multiply with like bases, add the exponents.


In the expression \(\frac {y^5} {y^3}\):

\(y^5=y \cdot y \cdot y \cdot y \cdot y\)

The exponent 5 means there are 5 factors of \(y\).

\(y^3=y \cdot y \cdot y\)

The exponent 3 means there are 3 factors of \(y\).

y 5 y 3 = y · y · y · y · y y · y · y = y · y

There are 2 factors of \(y\), which can be written as \(y^2\).

\(\frac {y^5}{y^3}=y^2\)

Notice the exponent is the difference of the exponents of the factors.

When you divide exponential expressions with the same base, you keep the base and subtract the exponents.


QUOTIENT PROPERTY FOR EXPONENTS

If \(a\) is a real number, \(a\neq0\), and \(m\) and \(n\) are integers, then

\(\frac{a^m}{a^n}=a^{m-n}\), \(m>n\) and \(\frac{a^m}{a^n}=\frac1{a^{n-m}}\), \(n>m\)


Here’s how to simplify expressions using properties of exponents.

  1. \(x^2 \cdot x^3\)

    2. The bases are the same. To multiply, use the Product Property for Exponents.

    \(x^2 \cdot x^3=x^{2+3}=x^5\). To multiply with like bases, add the exponents.

  2. \(y \cdot y^4\)

    3. The bases are the same. To multiply, use the Product Property for Exponents.

    Remember: A variable with no exponent shown has an exponent of \(1\), \(y=y^1\).

    \(y \cdot y^4=y^1 \cdot y^4=y^{1+4}=y^5\). To multiply with like bases, add the exponents.

  3. \(\frac {x^5}{x^2}\)

    4. The bases are the same. To divide, use the Quotient Property of Exponents.

    \(\frac {x^5}{x^2}=x^{5-2}=x^3\). To divide with like bases, subtract the exponents.

  4. \(\frac {x^4yz}{x^2y^2z}\)

    5. The expression contains like bases. Use the Quotient Property of Exponents.

    \(\frac{x^4yz}{x^2y^2z}=\frac{x^4y^1z^1}{x^2y^2z^1}=\frac{x^{4-2}z^{1-1}}{y^{2-1}}=\frac{x^2z^0}{y^1}=\frac{x^2}y\). To divide with like bases, subtract the exponents.

    Remember: Any nonzero number to the zero power is 1.

Try It: Simplify Expressions Using Properties of Exponents

Simplify the expressions.

  1. \(x^3 \cdot x^4\)
  2. \(\frac {x^9}{x^3}\)
  3. \(\frac {x^4y^2z^5}{x^6yz^3}\)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to simplify expressions using properties of exponents.

  1. \(x^3 \cdot x^4=x^{3+4}=x^7\). To multiply with like bases, add the exponents.
  2. \(\frac {x^9}{x^3}=x^{9-3}=x^6\). To divide with like bases, subtract the exponents.
  3. \(\frac {x^4y^2z^5}{x^6yz^3}=\frac {y^{2-1}z^{5-3}}{x^{6-4}}=\frac {yz^2}{x^2}\). To divide with like bases, subtract the exponents.

Check Your Understanding

----------------------------------------

Which expression is equivalent to \(y^6\)?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in the mini-lesson review. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(\frac {y^{12}}{y^6}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

------------------------------------

Videos

Watch the following videos to learn more about simplifying expressions with exponents.

Khan Academy: Exponent properties involving products

Watch this video to see how to multiply expressions with exponents.

VIDEO:


Khan Academy: Exponents properties with quotients

Watch this video to see how to divide expressions with exponents.

VIDEO:

page.title: Question #2: Simplify Expressions Using the Distributive Property
page.contents: Which expression is equivalent to \(-2(x-4)\)?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: To use the Distributive Property, multiply the factor outside the parentheses by each term inside the parentheses. The correct answer is \(-2x+8\).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: To use the Distributive Property, multiply the factor outside the parentheses by each term inside the parentheses. Watch the signs when multiplying. The correct answer is \(-2x+8\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: Multiply the factor outside the parentheses by each term inside the parentheses.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: To use the Distributive Property, multiply the factor outside the parentheses by each term inside the parentheses. Notice the 2 is negative. The correct answer is \(-2x+8\).

page.title: Simplify Expressions Using the Distributive Property: Mini-Lesson Review
page.contents:
Simplify Expressions Using the Distributive Property

The Distributive Property can be used to remove parentheses as you simplify expressions.


DISTRIBUTIVE PROPERTY

If a , b , c are real numbers, then a ( b + c ) = a b + a c Also, ( b + c ) a = b a + c a a ( b − c ) = a b − a c ( b − c ) a = b a − c a If a , b , c are real numbers, then a ( b + c ) = a b + a c Also, ( b + c ) a = b a + c a a ( b − c ) = a b − a c ( b − c ) a = b a − c a


Simplify:

  1. \(3(x+4)\)
    It may help to use arrows to show the Distributive Property.


    Use the Distributive Property.
    \(3 \cdot x+3 \cdot 4\)

    Multiply.
    \(3x+12\)
  1. \(-11(4-3a)\)
    Use arrows to show the Distributive Property.


    Use the Distributive Property.
    \(-11\cdot 4-(-11) \cdot 3a\)

    Multiply.
    \(-44-(-33a)\)

    Simplify.
    \(-44+33a\)

    Watch signs when using the Distributive Property with negative signs.

Try It: Simplify Expressions Using the Distributive Property


Simplify: \(-2(4y+1)\).

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to simplify expressions using the Distributive Property.

Use arrows to show the Distributive Property.

Use the Distributive Property.
\(-2 \cdot 4y+(-2) \cdot 1\)

Multiply.
\(-8y+(-2)\)

Simplify.
\(-8y-2\)


Check Your Understanding

Which expression is equivalent to \(4(5-2a)\)?

Correct! Check yourself: Multiply the factor outside the parentheses by each term inside the parentheses.

Try again. Let’s try again a different way: To use the Distributive Property, multiply the factor outside the parentheses by each term inside the parentheses.

The correct answer is \(20-8a\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


Videos

Watch the first 2 minutes and 40 seconds of the video to see how to use the Distributive Property to simplify expressions.

Khan Academy: Distributive property with variables

page.title: Question #3: Find the Greatest Common Factor
page.contents: Which is the greatest common factor of \(48\) and \(80\)?

answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The GCF is the product of the common factors, \(2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is a common factor of \(48\) and \(80\), but it’s not the greatest common factor. The correct answer is \(16\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is a factor of \(48\), but not of \(80\). The correct answer is \(16\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is a factor of \(80\), but not of \(48\). The correct answer is \(16\).

page.title: Find the Greatest Common Factor: Mini-Lesson Review
page.contents:
Find the Greatest Common Factor

The greatest common factor (GCF) of two or more expressions is the largest expression that is a factor of all the expressions.

Find the greatest common factor of \(54\) and \(36\).

Step 1
Factor each number into primes.
Factor \(54\) and \(36\).



Step 2
List the factors. In each column, circle the common factors.
Circle the \(2\), \(3\), and \(3\) that are shared by both numbers.

Step 3
Bring down the common factors that all the expressions share.
Bring down the \(2\), \(3\), and \(3\).
GCF \(=2 \cdot 3 \cdot 3\) 

Step 4
Multiply the factors.
Multiply the common factors \(2\), \(3\), and \(3\).
GCF \(=18\)
The GCF of \(54\) and \(36\) is \(18\).

Try It: Find the Greatest Common Factor


Find the greatest common factor (GCF) of \(84\) and \(56\).

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Here’s how to find the GCF.

Step 1 
Factor each number into primes.
Factor \(84\) and \(56\).



Step 2 
List the factors. In each column, circle the common factors.
Circle the \(2\), \(2\), and \(7\) that are shared by both numbers.

Step 3 
Bring down the common factors that all the expressions share.
Bring down the \(2\), \(2\), and \(7\).
GCF \(=227\)

Step 4 
Multiply the factors.
Multiply the common factors \(2\), \(2\), and \(7\).
GCF \(=28\)
The GCF of \(84\) and \(56\) is \(28\).


Check Your Understanding

Which is the greatest common factor of \(96\) and \(72\)?

Correct! Check yourself: The GCF is the product of the common factors, \(2 \cdot 2 \cdot 3\).

Try again. Take a moment to think about what you learned in the mini-lesson review. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(24\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


Videos

Watch the following video to learn more about finding the greatest common factor of two integers.

Khan Academy: Greatest common factor explained

page.title: Unit 6 Overview: Wrap Up
page.contents:
How did you do? Take a moment to reflect on how many answers you got right and wrong on the previous pages. Did you complete the mini-lesson reviews? If not, completing these resources can help you get a better understanding of these concepts:

  • Simplify expressions with exponents.
  • Simplify expressions using the Distributive Property.
  • Find the greatest common factor (GCF) of two or more numbers.

If you are still struggling, be sure to reach out to your teacher for additional help. Nobody is good at problems like this on the first try. Keep at it, and it will get easier.
